I am resolved without it; at thy pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: By my soul's safety then, sir, I protest.
My tongue shall never take knowledge of a word,
Delivered me in nature of your trust.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: It's too much, these ceremonies need not,
I know thy faith to be as firm as rock.
Thomas, come hither, near: we cannot be
Too private, in this business. So it is,
(Now, he has sworn, I dare the safelier venture)
I have of late, by divers observations —
(But, whether his oath can bind him, yea, or no',
Being not taken lawfully? ha? say you?
I will ask counsel, ere I do proceed:)
Thomas, it will be now too long to stay,
I'll spy some fitter time soon, or tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Sir, at your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: I will think. And, Thomas,
I pray you search the books 'gainst my return,
For the receipts 'twixt me, and traps.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I will, sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: And, hear you, if your mistress brother, Wellbred,
Chance to bring hither any gentlemen,
Ere I come back; let one straight bring me word.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Very well, sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: To the exchange; do you hear?
Or here in Colman-street, to justice Clements.
Forget it not, nor be not out of the way.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I will not, sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: I pray you have a care on't.
Or whether he come, or no, if any other,
Stranger, or else, fail not to send me word.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I shall not, sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Be't your special business
Now, to remember it.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Sir. I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: But, Thomas, this is not the secret, Thomas,
I told you of.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: No, sir. I do suppose it.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Believe me, it is not.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Sir. I do believe you.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: By heaven, it is not, that's enough. But, Thomas,
I would not, you should utter it, do you see?
To any creature living, yet, I care not.
Well, I must hence. Thomas, conceive thus much.
It was a trial of you, when I meant
So deep a secret to you, I mean not this,
But that I have to tell you, this is nothing, this.
But, Thomas, keep this from my wife, I charge you,
Locked up in silence, midnight, buried here.
No greater hell, than to be slave to fear.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Locked up in silence, midnight, buried here.
Whence should this flood of passion (Trow) take head? ha?
Best, dream no longer of this running humour,
For fear I sink! the violence of the stream
Already hath transported me so far,
That I can feel no ground at all! but soft,
O, 'tis our water-bearer: somewhat has crossed him, now.

sp.p: Fasting days? what tell you me of fasting days? 'slid, would they were all on a light fire for me: they say, the whole world shall be consumed with fire one day, but would I had these ember-weeks, and villainous Fridays burned, in the mean time, and then —

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Why, how now Cob, what moves thee to this choler? ha?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Collar, master Thomas? I scorn your collar, I sir, I am none o'your carthorse, though I carry, and draw water. An' you offer to ride me, with your collar, or halter either, I may hap show you a jade's trick, sir.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: O, you'll slip your head out of the collar? why, goodman Cob, you mistake me.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Nay, I have my rheum, and I can be angry as well as another, sir.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Thy rheum, Cob? thy humour, thy humour? thou mistakest.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Humour? mack, I think it be so, indeed: what is that humour? some rare thing, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Marry, I'll tell thee, Cob: it is a gentlemanlike monster, bred, in the special gallantry of our time, by affectation; and fed by folly.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: How? must it be fed?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: O ay, humour is nothing, if it be not fed. Didst thou never hear that? it's a common phrase, feed my humour.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: I'll none on it: humour, avant, I know you not, be gone. Let who will make hungry meals for your monster-ship, it shall not be I. Feed you, quoth he? 'slid, I ha'much ado, to feed myself; especially, on these lean rascally days, too; an't had been any other day, but a fasting day (A plague on them all for me) by this light, one might have done the commonwealth good service, and have drowned them all i' the flood, two or three hundred thousand years ago. O, I do stomach them hugely! I have a maw now, an't were for sirBevis his horse, against 'em.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: I pray thee, good Cob, what makes thee so out of love with fasting-dais?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Marry that, which will make any man out of love with 'em, I think: their bad conditions, and you will needs know. First, they are of a Flemish breed, I am sure on't, for they raven up more butter, than all the days of the week, beside; next, they stink of fish, and leek-porridge miserably: thirdly, they'll keep a man devoutly hungry, all day, and at night send him supperless to bed.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Indeed, these are faults, Cob.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Nay, and this were all, 'twere something, but they are the only known enemies, to my generation. A fasting-day, no sooner comes, but my lineage goes to rack, poor cobs they smoke for it, they are made martyrs o'the gridiron, they melt in passion: and your maids too know this, and yet would have me turn Hannibal, and eat my own fish, and blood:he pulls out a red herring. my princely couz, fear nothing; I have not the heart to devour you, and I might be made as rich as King Cophetva. O, that I had room for my tears, I could weep salt-water enough, now, to preserve the lives of ten thousand of my kin. But, I may curse none but these filthy almanacs, for an't were not for them, these days of persecution would never be known. I'll be hanged, an' some fishmongers son do not make of hem; and puts in more fasting-dais than he should do, because he would utter his father's dried stockfish, and stinking conger.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: 'Slight, peace, thou'lt be beaten like a stockfish, else: here is Mr. Matthew. Now must I look out for a messenger to my master.

div.head: Act iii. Scene v.
div.stage: Well-bred, Ed. Kno'well, Brainworm, Bobadill, Matthew, Stephen, Thomas, Cob.

sp.p: Beshrew me, but it was an absolute good jest, and exceedingly well carried!

sp.speaker: E. Kno.
sp.p: Ay, and our ignorance maintained it as well, did it not?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes faith, but was't possible thou shouldst not know him? I forgive Mr. Stephen, for he is stupidity itself!

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Before god, not I, and I might have been joined patten with one of the seven wise masters, for knowing him. He had so writhen himself, into the habit of one of your poor infantry, your decayed, ruinous, worm-eaten gentlemen of the round: such as have vowed to sit on the skirts of the city, let your Provost, and his half-dozen of halberdeers do what they can; and have translated begging out of the old hackney pace, to a fine easy amble, and made it run as smooth, of the tongue, as a shove-groat shilling. Into the likeness of one of these reformadoes had he moulded himself so perfectly, observing every trick of their action, as varying the accent, swearing with an emphasis, indeed all, with so special, and exquisite a grace, that (Hadst thou seen him) thou wouldst have sworn, he might have been sergeant-major, if not lieutenant-colonel to the regiment.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why, Brainworm, who would have thought thou hadst been such an artificer?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: An artificer? An architect! except a man had studied begging all his life-time, and been a weaver of language, from his infancy, for the clothing of it! I never saw his rival.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Where gottest thou this coat, I marl'e?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Of a Houndsditch man, sir. One of the devil's near kinsmen, a broker.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: That cannot be, if the proverb hold; for, a crafty knave needs no broker.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: True sir, but I did need a broker, ergo.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: (Well put off) no crafty knave, you'll say,

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Tut, he has more of these shifts.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: And yet where I have one, the broker has ten, sir,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Francis, Martin, never a one to be found, now? what a spite's this?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How now, Thomas? is my brother Kitely, within?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: No sir, my master went forth e'en now: but master downright is within. Cob, what Cob? is he gone too?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Whither went your master? Thomas, canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I know not, to justice Clements, I think, sir. Cob.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Justice Clement, what's he?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why, dost thou not know him? he is a city-magistrate, a justice here, an excellent good lawyer, and a great scholar: but the only mad, merry, old fellow in Europe! I showed him you, the other day.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: O, is that he? I remember him now. Good faith, and he has a very strange presence, methinks ; it shows as if he stood out of the rank, from other men: I have heard many of his jests i' university. They say, he will commit a man, for taking the wall, of his horse.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Ay, or wearing his cloak of one shoulder, or serving of god: any thing indeed, if it come in the way of his humour.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Cash goes in and out calling. Gasper, Martin, Cob: 'heart, where should they be, trow?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Master Kitely's man, pray thee vouchsafe us the lighting of this match.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Fire on your match, no time but now to vouchsafe? Francis. Cob.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Body of me! here's the remainder of seven pound, since yesterday was seven-night. 'tis your right Trinidado! did you never take any, master Stephen?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: No truly, sir? but I'll learn to take it now, since you commend it, so.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Sir, believe me (Upon my relation) for what I tell you, the world shall not reprove. I have been in the Indies (Where this herb grows) where neither myself, nor a dozen gentlemen more (Of my knowledge) have received the taste of any other nutriment, in the world, for the space of one and twenty weeks, but the fume of this simple only. Therefore, it cannot be, but 'tis most divine! Further, take it in the nature, in the true kind so, it makes an antidote, that (Had you taken the most deadly poisonous plant in all Italy, it should expel it, and clarify you, with as much ease, as I speak. And, for your green wound, your balsamum, and your st. John's wort are all mere gulleries, and trash to it, especially your Trinidado: your nicotian is good too. I could say what I know of the virtue of it, for the expulsion of rheums, raw humours, crudities, obstructions, with a thousand of this kind, but I profess myself no quacksalver. Only, thus much, by Hercules, I do hold it, and will affirm it (Before any prince in Europe) to be the most sovereign, and precious weed, that ever the earth tendered to the use of man.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: This speech would ha' done decently in a tabacco-trader's mouth!

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: At justice Clement's, he is: in the middle of Colman-street.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O, o?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Where's the match I gave thee? Master Kitely's man?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Would his match, and he, and pipe, and all were at sancto Domingo! I had forgotten it.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p:
By gods me, I mar'le, what pleasure, or felicity they have in taking this roguish tobacco! it's good for nothing, but to choke a man, and fill him full of smoke, and embers: there were four died out of one
house, last week, with taking of it, and two more the bell went for, yesternight; one of them (They say) will never scape it: he voided a bushel of soot yesterday, upward, and downward. By the stocks, an' there were no wiser men than I, I'd have it present whipping, man, or woman, that should but deal with a tobacco-pipe; why, it will stifle them all in the end, as many as use it; it's little better than rat's bane, or rosaker.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O,Bobadil beats him with a cudgel. good captain, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: You base cullion, you.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.p: Sir, here's your match: come, thou must needs be talking, too, thou'rt well enough served.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Nay, he will not meddle with his match, I warrant you: well it shall be a dear beating, and I live.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Do you prate? Do you murmur?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Nay, good captain, will you regard the humour of a fool? away, knave.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Thomas, get him away.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: A whoreson filthy slave, a dung-worm, an excrement! Body of Caesar, but that I scorn to let forth so mean a spirit, I'd ha' stabbed him, to the earth.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Marry, the law forbid, sir.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: By Pharaoh's foot, I would have done it.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: O, he swears admirably! (By Pharaoh's foot) (Body of Caesar) I shall never do it, sure (Upon mine honour, and by saint George) no, I ha' not the right grace.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Master Stephen, will you any? By this air, the most divine tobacco, that ever I drunk!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: None, I thank you, sir. O, this gentleman does it, rarely too! but nothing like the other. By this air, as I am a gentleman: by —

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Master,master Stephen is practising, to the post. glance, glance! Master Well-bred!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: As I have somewhat to be saved, I protest —

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You are a fool: it needs no affidavit.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Cousin, will you any tobacco?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Ay sir! upon my reputation —

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: How now, cousin!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: I protest, as I am a gentleman, but no soldier, indeed —

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: No, master Stephen? as I remember your name is entered in the artillery garden?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Ay sir, that's true: cousin, may I swear, as I am a soldier, by that?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: O yes, that you may. It's all you have for your money.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Then, as I am a gentleman, and a soldier, it is divine tobacco!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: But soft, where's Mr. Matthew? gone?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: No, sir, they went in here.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: O, let's follow them: master Matthew is gone to salute his mistress, in verse. We shall ha' the happiness, to hear some of his poetry, now. He never comes unfurnished. Brainworm?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Brainworm? Where? Is this Brainworm?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Ay, cousin, no words of it, upon your gentility.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Not I, body of me, by this air, s. George, and the foot of Pharaoh.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Rare! your cousin's discourse is simply drawn out with oaths.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: 'Tis larded with 'em. A kind of French dressing, if you love it.
Ha? how many are there, sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Marry sir, your brother, master well-bred —

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Tut, beside him: what strangers are there, man?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Strangers? let me see, one, two; mass I know not well, there are so many.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: How? so many?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Ay, there's some five, or six of them, at the most.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: A swarm, a swarm,
Spite of the devil, how they sting my head
With forked stings, thus wide, and large! But, Cob,
How long hast thou been coming hither, Cob?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: A little while, sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Didst thou come running?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: No, sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: Nay, than I am familiar with thy haste!
Bane to my fortunes: what meant I to marry?
Ay, that before was ranked in such content,
My mind at rest too, in so soft a peace,
Being free master of mine own free thoughts,
And now become a slave? What? never sigh,
Be of good cheer, man: for thou art a cuckold,
'Tis done, 'tis done! nay, when such flowing store,
Plenty itself, falls in my wife's lap,
The cornucopia will be mine, I know. But, Cob,
What entertainment had they? I am sure
My sister, and my wife, would bid them welcome! ha?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Like enough, sir, yet, I heard not a word of it.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: No: their lips were sealed with kisses, and the voice
Drowned in a flood of joy, at their arrival,
Had lost her motion, state, and faculty.
Cob, which of them was't, that first kissed my wife?
(My sister, I should say) my wife, alas,
I fear not her: ha? who was it, say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: By my troth, sir, will you have the truth of it?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.l: O ay, good Cob: I pray thee, heartily.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Then, I am a vagabond, and fitter for Bridewell, than your worship's company, if I saw anybody to be kissed, unless they would have kissed the post, in the middle of the warehouse; for there I left them all, at their tobacco, with a pox.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: How? were they not gone in, then, ere thou cam'st?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O no sir.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Spite of the devil ▪ what do I stay here, then? Cob, follow me.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Nay, soft and fair, I have eggs on the spit; I cannot go yet, sir. Now am I for some five and fifty reasons hammering, hammering revenge: o, for three or four gallons of vinegar, to sharpen my wits. Revenge, vinegar revenge: vinegar, and mustard revenge: nay, and he had not lyen in my house, 't would never have grieved me, but being my guest, one, that I'll be sworn, my wife has lent him her smock off her back, while his one shirt has been at washing; pawned her neckerchers for clean bands for him; sold almost all my platters, to buy him tobacco; and he to turn monster of ingratitude, and strike his lawful host! well, I hope to raise up an host of fury for't: here comes justice Clement.
What's master Kitely gone? Roger?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Ay, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: 'heart of me! what made him leave us so abruptly! How now, sirrah? what make you here? what would you have, ha?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: An't please your worship, I am a poor neighbour of your worships —

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: A poor neighbour of mine? why, speak poor neighbour.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: I dwell, sir, at the sign of the water-tankard, hard by the green lattice: I have paid Scot, and lot there, any time this eighteen years.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: To the green lattice?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: No, sir, to the parish: marry, I have seldom 'scaped scotfree, at the lattice.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: O, well! what business has my poor neighbour with me?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: An't like your worship, I am come, to crave the peace of your worship.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Of me knave? peace of me, knave? did I e'er hurt thee? or threaten thee? or wrong thee? ha?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: No, sir, but your worship's warrant, for one that has wronged me, sir: his arms are at too much liberty, I would fain have them bound to a treaty of peace, an' my credit could compass it, with your worship.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Thou goest far enough about for't, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Why, dost thou go in danger of thy life for him? friend?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: No sir; but I go in danger of my death, every hour, by his means: an' I die, within a twelvemonth and a day, I may swear, by the law of the land, that he killed me.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: How? how knave? swear he killed thee? and by the law? what pretence? what colour hast thou for that?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Marry, an't please your worship, both black, and blew; colour enough, I warrant you. I have it here, to show your worship.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What is he, that gave you this, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: A gentleman, and a soldier, he says he is, o'the city here.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: A soldier of the city? What call you him?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Captain Bobadil.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Bobadil? And why did he bob, and beat you, sirrah? How began the quarrel betwixt you? ha: speak truly knave, I advise you.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Marry, indeed, and please your worship, only because I spoke against their vagrant tobacco, as I came by 'em, when they were taking on't, for nothing else.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Ha? you speak against tobacco? Formal, his name.

sp.speaker: Form.
sp.p: What's your name, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Oliver, sir, Oliver Cob, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Tell Oliver Cob, he shall go to the jail, formal.

sp.speaker: Form.
sp.p: Oliver Cob, my master, justice Clement, says, you shall go to the jail.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O, I beseech your worship, for god's sake, dear master justice.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Nay, gods precious: and such drunkards, and tankards, as you are, come to dispute of tobacco once; I have done! away with him.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O, good master justice, sweet old gentleman.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Sweet Oliver, would I could do thee any good: justice Clement, let me entreat you, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What? A threadbare rascal! A beggar! A slave that never drunk out of better than pisspot mettle in his life! and he to deprave, and abuse the virtue of an herb, so generally received in the courts of princes, the chambers of nobles, the bowers of sweet ladies, the cabins of soldiers! Roger, away with him, by gods precious — I say, go too.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Dear master justice; let me be beaten again, I have deserved it: but not the prison, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Alas, poor Oliver!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Roger, make him a warrant (He shall not go) I but fear the knave.

sp.speaker: Form.
sp.p: Do not stink, sweet Oliver, you shall not go, my master will give you a warrant.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O, the lord maintain his worship, his worthy worship.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Away, dispatch him. How now, master Kno'well! In dumps? In dumps? Come, this becomes not.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Sir, would I could not feel my cares —

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Your cares are nothing! they are like my cap, soon put on, and as soon put off. What? your son is old enough, to govern himself: let him run his course, it's the only way to make him a staid man. If he were an unthrift, a ruffian, a drunkard, or a licentious liver, than you had reason; you had reason to take care: but, being none of these, mirth's my witness, an' I had twice so many cares, as you have, I'd drown them all in a cup of sack. Come, come, let's try it: I muse, your parcel of a soldier returns not all this while.
Well sister, I tell you true: and you'll find it so, in the end.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Alas brother, what would you have me to do? I cannot help it: you see, my brother brings 'em in, here, they are his friends.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: His friends? his fiends. 'sblood, they do nothing but haunt him, up and down, like a sort of unlucky sprites, and tempt him to all manner of villainy, that can be thought of. Well, by this light, a little thing would make me play the devil with some of 'em; and 'twere not more for your husband's sake, than any thing else, I'd make the house too hot for the best on hem: they should say, and swear, hell were broken loose, ere they went hence. But, by gods will, 'tis nobody's fault, but yours: for, an' you had done, as you might have done, they should have been parboiled, and baked too, every mother's son, ere they should ha' come in, ere a one of 'em.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: God's my life! did you ever hear the like? what a strange man is this! Could I keep out all them, think you? I should put myself, against half a dozen men? should I? Good faith, you'd mad the patientest body in the world, to hear you talk so, without any sense, or reason!

div.head: Act iv. Scene ii.
div.stage: Mrs. Bridget, Mr. Matthew, dame Kitely, downe-right, Wel-bred, Stephen, Ed. Kno'well, Bobadil, Brainworm, gash.

sp.l: Servant (In troth) you are too prodigal
Of your wit's treasure, thus to pour it forth,
Upon so mean a subject, as my worth?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You say well, mistress; and I mean, as well.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.l: Heyday, here is stuff!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: O, now stand close: pray heaven, she can get him to read:
He should do it, of his own natural impudency.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.l: Servant, what is this same, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.l: Marry, an elegy, an elegy, an odd toy —

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.l: To mock an ape withal. O, I could sow up his mouth, now.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: Sister, I pray you let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.l: Are you rime-given, too?

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.l: Mistress, I'll read it, if you please.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.l: Pray you do, servant.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.l: O, here's no foppery! Death, I can endure the stocks, better.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: What ails thy brother? can he not hold his water, at reading of a ballad?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: O, no: a rhyme to him, is worse than cheese, or a bagpipe. But, mark, you lose the protestation.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Faith, I did it in an humour; I know not how it is: but, please you come near, sir. This gentleman has judgement, he knows how to censure of a — pray you sir, you can judge.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Not I, sir: upon my reputation, and, by the foot of Pharaoh.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: O, chide your cousin, for swearing.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Not I, so long as he does not for swear himself.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Master Matthew, you abuse the expectation of your dear mistress, and her fair sister: fie, while you live, avoid this prolixity.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: I shall, sir: well, incipere dulce.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: How! Insipere dulce? A sweet thing to be a fool, indeed.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: What, do you take insipere, in that sense?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: You do not? you? This was your villainy, to gull him with a mot.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: O, the bencher's phrase: pauca verba, pauca verba.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.l: Rare creature, let me speak without offence,
Would god my rude words had the influence,
To rule thy thoughts, as thy fair looks do mine,
Then shouldst thou be his prisoner, who is thine.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.l: This is in hero and Leander?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: O, I! peace, we shall have more of this.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.l: Be not unkind, and fair, mishapen stuff
Is of behaviour boisterous, and rough:

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: master Stephen answer with shaking his head. how like you that, sir?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: 'Slight, he shakes his head like a bottle, to feel and there be any brain in it!

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.l: But observe the catastrophe, now,
And I in duty will exceed all other,
As you in beauty do excel love's mother.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Well, I'll have him free of the wit-brokers, for he utters nothing, but stolen remnants.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: O, forgive it him.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: A filching rogue? hang him. And, from the dead? it's worse than sacrilege.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sister, what ha' you here? verses? pray you, let's see. Who made these verses? they are excellent good!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O, master Wellbred, 'tis your disposition to say so, sir. They were good i' the morning, I made 'em, extempore, this morning.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How? extempore?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ay, would I might be hanged else: ask captain Bobadile. He saw me write them, at the — (Pox on it) the star, yonder.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Can he find, in his heart, to curse the stars, so?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Faith, his are even with him: they ha' cursed him enough already.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Cousin, how do you like this gentleman's verses?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: O, admirable! the best that ever I heard, coz!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Body of Caesar! they are admirable!
The best, that ever I heard, as I am a soldier.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: I am vexed, I can hold never a bone of me still! Heart, I think, they mean to build, and breed here!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sister, you have a simple servant here, that crowns your beauty, with such encomions, and devises: you may see, what it is to be the mistress of a wit! that can make your perfections so transparent, that every blear eye may look through them, and see him drowned over head, and ears, in the deep well of desire. Sister Kitely, I marvel, you get you not a servant, that can rhyme, and do tricks, too.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: O monster! impudence itself! tricks?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Tricks, brother? what tricks?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Nay, speak, I pray you, what tricks?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Ay, never spare anybody here: but say, what tricks?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Passion of my heart! do tricks?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: 'Slight, here's a trick vied, and reuyed! why, you monkeys, you? what a caterwauling do you keep? has he not given you rhymes, and verses, and tricks?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: O, the fiend!

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Nay, you, lamp of virginity, that take it in snuff so! come, and cherish this tame poetical fury, in your servant, you'll be begged else, shortly, for a concealment: go to, reward his muse. You cannot give him less than a shilling, in conscience, for the book, he had it out of, cost him a teston, at least. How now, gallants? mr. Matthew? Captain? What? all sons of silence? no spirit?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Come, you might practise your ruffian-tricks somewhere else, and not here, I wiss: this is no tavern, nor drinking-school, to vent your exploits in.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: How now! whose cow has calved?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Marry, that has mine, sir. Nay, boy, never look askance at me, for the matter; I'll tell you of it, ay, sir, you, and your companions, mend yourselves, when I ha' done?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: My companions?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Yes sir, you companions, so I say, I am not afraid of you, nor them neither: your hang-byes here. You must have your poets, and your potlings, your soldadoes, and fooladoes, to follow you up and down the city, and here they must come to domineer, and swagger. Sirrah, you, ballad-singer, and slops, your fellow there, get you out; get you home: or (By this steel) I'll cut off your ears, and that, presently.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: 'Slight, stay, let's see what he dare do: cut off his ears? cut a whetstone. You are an ass, do you see? touch any man here, and by this hand, I'll run my rapier to the hilts in you.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: they all draw, and they of the house make out to part them. yea, that would I fain see, boy.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: O Jesu! murder. Thomas, Gaspar!

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.p: Help, help, Thomas.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Gentlemen, forbear, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Well, sirrah, you, Holofernes: by my hand, I will pink your flesh, full of holes, with my rapier for this; I will, by this good heaven: nay,they offer to fight again, and are parted. let him come, let him come, gentlemen, by the body of saint George, I'll not kill him.

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: Hold, hold, good gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: You whoreson, bragging coistrel:

sp.l: Why, how now? what's the matter? what's the stir here?
Whence springs the quarrel? Thomas! where is he?
Put up your weapons, and put off this rage.
My wife and sister, they are cause of this,
What, Thomas? where is this knave?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Here, sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come, let's go: this is one of my brother's ancient humours, this.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: I am glad, nobody was hurt by his ancient humour.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: Why, how now, brother, who endorsed this brawl?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: A sort of lewd rake-hells, that care neither for god, nor the devil! And, they must come here to read ballads, and roguery, and trash! I'll mar the knot of 'em ere I sleep, perhaps: especially bob, there: he that's all manner of shapes! and songs, and sonnets, his fellow.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.l: Brother, indeed, you are too violent,
Too sudden, in your humour: and, you know
my brother Wel-bred's temper will not bear
Any reproof, chiefly in such a presence,
Where every slight disgrace, he should receive,
Might wound him in opinion, and respect.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.l: Respect? what talk you of respect among such,
As ha' nor spark of manhood, nor good manners?
'Sdeynes I am ashamed, to hear you! respect?

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.l: Yes, there was one a civil gentleman,
And very worthily demeaned himself!

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: O, that was some love of yours, sister!

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.l: A love of mine? I would it were no worse, brother!
You'd pay my portion sooner, than you think for.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Indeed, he seemed to be a gentleman of an exceeding fair disposition, and of very excellent good parts!

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Her love, by heaven! my wife's minion!
Fair disposition? excellent good parts?
Death, these phrases are intolerable!
Good parts? how should she know his parts?
His parts? Well, well, well, well, well, well!
It is too plain, too clear: Thomas, come hither.
What, are they gone?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: Ay, sir, they went in.
My mistress, and your sister —

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Are any of the gallants within!

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: No, sir, they are all gone.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Art thou sure of it?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.l: I can assure you, sir.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: What gentleman was that they praised so, Thomas?

sp.speaker: Cash.
sp.p: One, they call him master Kno'well, a handsome young gentleman, sir.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Ay, I thought so: my mind gave me as much.
I'll die, but they have hid him i' the house,
Somewhere; I'll go and search: go with me, Thomas.
Be true to me, and thou shalt find me a master.

sp.p: What Tib, Tib, I say.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: How now, what cuckold is that knocks so hard? O, husband, is't you? what's the news?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Nay, you have stunned me, i'faith! you ha' given me a knock of the forehead, will stick by me! cuckold? 'slid, cuckold?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Away, you fool, did I know it was you, that knocked?
Come, come, you may call me as bad, when you list.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: May I? Tib, you are a whore.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: You lie in your throat, husband.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: How, the lie? and in my throat too? do you long to be stabbed, ha?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Why, you are no soldier, I hope?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O, must you be stabbed by a soldier? Mass, that's true! when was Bobadill here? your captain? that rogue, that foist, that fencing burgullian? I'll tickle him, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter? trow!

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: O, he has basted me, rarely, sumptuously! but I have it herein black and white; for his black, and blew: shall pay him. O, the justice! the honestest old brave Trojan in London! I do honour the very flea of his dog. A plague on him though, he put me once in a villainous filthy fear; marry, it vanished away, like the smoke of tobacco: but I was smoked soundly first. I thank the devil, and his good angel, my guest. Well, wife, or Tib (Which you will) get you in, and lock the door, I charge you, let nobody in to you; wife, nobody in, to you: those are my words. Not captain bob himself, nor the fiend, in his likeness; you are a woman; you have flesh and blood enough in you, to be tempted: therefore, keep the door, shut, upon all comers.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: I warrant you, there shall nobody enter here, without my consent.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Nor, with your consent, sweet Tib, and so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: It's more, than you know, whether you leave me so.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Why, sweet.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Tut, sweet, or sour, thou art a flower,
Keep close thy door, I ask no more.
Well Brainworm, perform this business, happily,
And thou makest a purchase of my love, forever,

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I'faith, now let thy spirits use their best faculties. but, at any hand, remember the message, to my brother: for, there's no other means, to start him.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I warrant you, sir, fear nothing: I have a nimble soul has waked all forces of my fantasy, by this time, and put 'em in true motion. What you have possessed me withal, I'll discharge it amply, sir. Make it no question.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Forth, and prosper, Brainworm. Faith, Ned, how dost thou approve of my abilities in this device?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Troth, well, howsoever: but, it will come excellent, if it take.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Take, man? why, it cannot choose but take, if the circumstances miscarry not: but, tell me, ingenuously, dost thou affect my sister Bridget, as thou pretendest?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Friend, am I worth belief?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come, do not protest. In faith, she is a maid of good ornament, and much modesty: and, except I conceived very worthily of her, thou shouldst not have her.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Nay, that I am afraid will be a question yet, whether I shall have her, or no?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: 'Slid, thou shalt have her; by this light, thou shalt.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Nay, do not swear.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: By this hand, thou shalt have her: I'll go fetch her, presently. Point, but where to meet, and as I am an honest man, I'll bring her.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Hold, hold, be temperate.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why, by — what shall I swear by? thou shalt have her, as I am —

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Pray thee, be at peace, I am satisfied: and do believe, thou wilt omit no offered occasion, to make my desires complete.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Thou shalt see, and know, I will not.

sp.l: Was your man a soldier, sir?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Ay, a knave, I took him begging of the way,
This morning, as I came over Morefields!
O, here he is! ye have made fair speed, believe me:
Where, i' the name of sloth, could you be thus —

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Marry, peace be my comfort, where I thought I should have had little comfort of your worship's service.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: O, sir! your coming to the city, your entertainment of me, and your sending me to watch — indeed, all the circumstances either of your charge, or my employment, are as open to your son, as to yourself!

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: How should that be! unless that villain, Brainworm,
Have told him of the letter, and discovered
All that I strictly charged him to conceal? 'tis so!

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.l: I am, partly, of the faith, 'tis so indeed.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: But, how should he know thee to be my man?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.l: This is strange, and barbarous! as ever I heard!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Nay, for a more instance of their preposterous natures, but note, sir. They have assaulted me some three, four, five, six of them together, as I have walked alone, in divers skirts i' the town, as Turnbull, Whitechapel, Shoreditch, which were then my quarters, and since upon the exchange, at my lodging, and at my ordinary: where I have driven them afore me, the whole length of a street, in the open view of all our gallants, pitying to hurt them, believe me. Yet, all this lenity will not o'ercome their spleen: they will be doing with the pismire, raising a hill, a man may spurn abroad, with his foot, at pleasure. By myself, I could have slain them all, but I delight not in murder. I am loath to bear any other than this bastinado for 'em: yet, I hold it good polity, not to go disarmed, for though I be skilful, I may be oppressed with multitudes.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Ay, believe me, may you sir: and (In my conceit) our whole nation should sustain the loss by it, if it were so.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Alas, no: what's a peculiar man, to a nation? not seen.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: O, but your skill, sir!

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Indeed, that might be some loss; but, who respects it? I will tell you, sir, by the way of private, and under seal; I am a gentleman, and live here obscure, and to myself: but, were I known to her majesty, and the lords (Observe me) I would undertake (Upon this poor head, and life) for the public benefit of the state, not only to spare the entire lines of her subjects in general, but to save the one half, nay, three parts of her yearly charge, in holding war, and against what enemy soever. And, how would I do it, think you?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Nay, I know not, nor can I conceive.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Why thus, sir. I would select nineteen, more, to myself, throughout the land; gentlemen they should be of good spirit, strong, and able constitution, i would choose them by an instinct, a character, that I have: and I would teach these nineteen, the special rules, as your punto, your reverso, your stoccata, your imbroccata, your passada, your Montanto: till they could all play very near, or altogether as well as myself. This done, say the enemy were forty thousand strong, we twenty would come into the field, the tenth of march, or thereabouts; and we would challenge twenty of the enemy; they could not, in their honour, refuse us, well, we would kill them: challenge twenty more, kill them; twenty more, kill them; twenty more, kill them too; and thus, would we kill, every man, his twenty a day, that's twenty score; twenty score, that's two hundreth; two hundreth a day, five days a thousand; forty thousand; forty times five, five times forty, two hundreth days kills them all up, by computation. And this, will I venture my poor gentlemanlike carcase, to perform (Provided, there be no treason practised upon us) by fair, and discreet manhood, that is, civilly by the sword.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Why, are you so sure of your hand, captain, at all times?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Tut, never miss thrust, upon my reputation with you.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: I would not stand in Downe-right's state, then, an' you meet him, for the wealth of any one street in London.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Why, sir, you mistake me! if he were here now, by this welkin, I would not draw my weapon on him! let this gentleman do his mind: but, I will bastinado him (By the bright sun) wherever I meet him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Faith, and I'll have a fling at him, at my distance.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: God's so ',downright walks over the stage. look, where he is: yonder he goes.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: What peevish luck have I, I cannot meet with these bragging rascals?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: It's not he? is it?

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Yes faith, it is he?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll be hanged, then, if that were he.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Sir, keep your hanging good, for some greater matter, for I assure you, that was he.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Upon my reputation, it was he.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Had I thought it had been he, he must not have gone so: but I can hardly be induced, to believe, it was he, yet.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: That I think, sir. But see, he is come again!

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: O, Pharaoh's foot, have I found you? Come, draw, to your tools: draw, Gipsy, or I'll thresh you.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Gentleman of valour, I do believe in thee, hear me —

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Draw your weapon, then.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Tall man, I never thought on it, till now (Body of me) I had a warrant of the peace, served on me, even now, as I came along, by a water-bearer; this gentleman saw it, Mr. Matthew.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, you will not draw, then?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Hold,he beats him, and disarms him: Matthew runs away. hold, under thy favour, forbear.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Prate again, as you like this, you whoreson foist, you. You'll control the point, you? Your consort is gone? had he stayed, he had shared with you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, bear witness, I was bound to the peace, by this good day.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: No faith, it's an ill day, captain, never reckon it other: but, say you were bound to the peace, the law allows you, to defend yourself: that'll prove but a poor excuse.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I cannot tell, sir. I desire good construction, in fair sort. I never sustained the like disgrace (By heaven) sure I was struck with a planet thence, for I had no power to touch my weapon.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p:
Ay, like enough, I have heard of many that have been beaten under a planet: go, get you to a surgeon. 'slid, an' these be your tricks, your passadas, and your mountantoes, I'll none of them. O, manners! that
this age should bring forth such creatures! that nature should be at leisure to make hem! Come, coz.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Mass, I'll ha' this cloak.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: God's will, 'tis Downright's.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Nay, it's mine now, another might have ta'en up, as well as I: I'll wear it, so I will.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: How, an' he see it? he'll challenge it, assure yourself.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Ay, but he shall not ha' it; I'll say, I bought it.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Take heed, you buy it not, too dear, coz.

div.head: Act iv. Scene viii.
div.stage: Kitely, Wel-bred, dame Kit. Bridget, Brainworm, Cash.

sp.l: Now, trust me brother, you were much to blame,
T'incense his anger, and disturb the peace,
Of my poor house, where there are sentinels,
That every minute watch, to give alarms,
Of civil war, without adjection
Of your assistance, or occasion.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: No harm done, brother, I warrant you: since there is no harm done. Anger costs a man nothing: and a tall man is never his own man, till he be angry. To keep his valour in obscurity, is to keep himself, as it were, in a cloak-bag. What's a musician, unless he play? what's a tall man, unless he fight? For, indeed, all this, my wise brother stands upon, absolutely: and, that made me fall in with him, so resolutely.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Ay, but what harm might have come of it, brother?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Might, sister? so, might the good warm clothes, your husband wears, be poisoned, for any thing he knows: or the wholesome wine he drunk, even now, at the table —

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Now, god forbid: oh me. Now, I remember,
My wife drunk to me, last; and changed the cup:
And bade me wear this cursed suit today.
See, if heaven suffer murder undiscovered!
I feel me ill; give me some mithridate,
Some mithridate and oil, good sister, fetch me;
Oh, I am sick at heart! I burn, I burn.
If you will save my life, go, fetch it me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: O, strange humour! my very breath has poisoned him.

sp.speaker: Brid.
sp.l: Good brother, be content, what do you mean?
The strength of these extreme conceits, will kill you.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p:
Beshrew your heartblood, brother Well-bred, now;
for putting such a toy into his head.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Is a fit simile, a toy? will he be poisoned with a simile? Brother Kitely, what a strange, and idle imagination is this? For shame, be wiser. On my soul, there's no such matter.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Am I not sick? how am I, then, not poisoned?
Am I not poisoned? how am I, then, so sick?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: If you be sick, your own thoughts make you sick.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: His jealousy is the poison, he has taken.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Mr. Kitely,he comes disguised like justice Clement's man. my master, justice Clement, salutes you; and desires to speak with you, with all possible speed.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: No time, but now? when, I think, I am sick? very sick! well, I will wait upon his worship. Thomas, Cob, I must seek them out, and set 'em sentinels, till I return. Thomas, Cob, Thomas.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: This is perfectly rare, Brainworm! but how gottest thou this apparel of the justice's man?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Marry sir, my proper fine penman, would needs bestow the grist o'me, at the windmill, to hear some martial discourse; where so I marshaled him, that I made him drunk, with admiration! And, because, too much hear was the cause of his distemper, I stripped him stark naked, as he lay along asleep, and borrowed his suit, to deliver this counterfeit message in, leaving a rusty armour, and an old brown bill to watch him, till my return: which shall be, when I ha' pawned his apparel, and spent the better part of the money, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Well, thou art a successful merry knave, Brainworm, his absence will be a good subject for more mirth. I pray thee, return to thy young master, and will him to meet me, and my sister Bridget, at the tower instantly: for, here, tell him, the house is so stored with jealousy, there is no room for love, to stand upright in. We must get our fortunes committed to some larger prison, say; and, than the tower, I know no better air: nor where the liberty of the house may do us more present service. Away.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Come hither, Thomas. Now, my secret's ripe,
And thou shalt have it; lay to both thine ears.
Hark, what I say to thee. I must go forth, Thomas.
Be careful of thy promise, keep good watch,
Note every gallant, and observe him well,
That enters in my absence, to thy mistress:
If she would show him rooms, the jest is stale,
Follow 'em, Thomas, or else hang on him,
And let him not go after; mark their looks;
Note, if she offer but to see his band,
Or any other amorous toy, about him;
But praise his leg; or foot; or if she say,
The day is hot, and bid him feel her hand,

sp.p: Master, you shall be well considered, I assure you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Sir, you know my service is my living, such favours as these, gotten of my master, is his only preferment, and therefore, you must consider me, as I may make benefit of my place.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How is that? sir.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Faith sir, the thing is extraordinary, and the gentleman may be, of great account: yet, be what he will, if you will lay me down a brace of angels, in my hand, you shall have it, otherwise not.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How shall we do, captain? he asks a brace of angels, you have no money?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Not a cross, by fortune.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Nor I, as I am a gentleman, but two pence, left of my two shillings in the morning for wine, and reddish: let's find him some pawn.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Pawn? we have none to the value of his demand.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O, yes. I'll pawn this jewel in my ear, and you may pawn your silk stockings, and pull up your boots, they will never be missed: it must be done, now.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Well, an' there be no remedy: I'll step aside, and pull 'em off.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Do you hear, sir? we have no store of money at this time, but you shall have good pawns: look you, sir, this jewel, and that gentleman's silk stockings, because we would have it dispatched, ere we went to our chambers.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I am content, sir; I will get you the warrant presently, what's his name, say you? Downright?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ay, ay, George downright.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: What manner of man is he?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: A tall big man, sir; he goes in a cloak, most commonly, of silk russet, laid about with russet lace.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: 'Tis very good, sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Here sir, here's my jewel?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: And, here, are stockings.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, I'll procure you this warrant presently, but, who will you have to serve it?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: That's true, captain: that must be considered.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Body of me, I know not! 'tis service of danger?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Why, you were best get one of the varlets of the city, a sergeant. I'll appoint you one, if you please.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Will you, sir? why, we can wish no better.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: We'll leave it to you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: This is rare! now, will I go pawn this cloak of the justice's man's, at the brokers, for a varlet's suit, and be the varlet myself; and get either more pawns, or more movie of downright, for the arrest.

div.head: Act iv. Scene x.
div.stage: Kno'wel, Tib, Cash, dame Kitely, Kitely, Cob.

sp.l: O, here it is, I am glad: I have found it now.
Ho? who is within, here?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I am within, sir, what's your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: To know, who is within, besides yourself.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Why, sir, you are no constable, I hope?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: O! fear you the constable? then, I doubt not.
You have some guests within, deserve that fear,
I'll fetch him straight.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: On god's name, sir.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Go to. Come, tell me, is not young Kno'well, here?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Young Kno'well? I know none such, sir, of mine honesty!

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Your honesty? dame, it flies too lightly from you:
There is no way, but, fetch the constable.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: The constable? the man is mad, I think.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Ho, who keeps house, here?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: O, this is the female copesmate of my son?
Now shall I meet him straight.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: Knock, Thomas, hand.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Ho, good wife?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: Why, woman, grieves it you to ope your door?
Belike, you get something, to keep it shut.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: What mean these questions, pray ye?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: So strange you make it? is not my husband, here?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Her husband!

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: My tried husband, master Kitely.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: I hope, he needs not to betrayed, here.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: No, dame: he does it not for need, but pleasure.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Neither for need, nor pleasure, is he here.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: This is but a device, to balk me withal.
Soft, who is this? 'tis not my son, disguised?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: O,she spies her husband come: and runs to him. sir, have I forestalled your honest market?
Found your close walks? you stand amazed, now, do you?
I'faith (I am glad) I have smoked you yet at last!
What is your jewel trow? In: come, let's see her;
(Fetch forth your housewife, dame) if she be fairer,
In any honest judgement, than myself,
I'll be content with it: but, she is change,
She feeds you fat, she soothes your appetite,
and you are well? your wife, an honest woman,
Is meat twice sod to you, sir? O, you trencher!

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: She cannot counterfeit thus palpably.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Out on thy more than strumpet's impudence!
Stealest thou thus to thy haunts? and, have I taken
Thy bawd, and thee, and thy companion,
pointing to old Knowell. this hoary-headed lecher, this old goat,
Close at your villainy, and wouldst thou excuse it,
With this stale harlots jest, accusing me?
to him. o, old incontinent, dost not thou shame,
When all thy powers in chastity is spent,
To have a mind so hot? and to entice,
And feed th'enticements of a lustful woman?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: Out, I defy thee, ay, dissembling wretch.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: by Thomas. defy me, strumpet? ask thy pandar, here,
Can be deny it? or that wicked older?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Why, hear you, sir.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Tut, tut, tut: never speak.
Thy guilty conscience will discover thee.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: What lunacy is this, that haunts this man?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Well, goodwife Baed, Cob's wife; and you,
That make your husband such a hoddie-doddie;
And you, young apple-squire; and old cuckold-maker;
He ha'you every one before a justice:
Nay, you shall answer it, I charge you go.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Marry, with all my heart, sir: I go willingly.
Though I do taste this as a trick, put on me,
To punish my impertinent search; and justly:
And half forgive my son, for the device.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Come, will you go?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: Go? to thy shame, believe it.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter, here? What's here to do?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: O, Cob, art thou come? I have been abused,
And i' thy house. Never was man so, wronged!

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: 'Slid, in my house? my master Kitely? Who wrongs you in my house?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Marry, young lust in old; and old in young, here:
Thy wife's their bawd, here have I taken 'em.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: he falls upon his wife and bears her. how? bawd? Is my house come to that? Am I preferred thither? Did I charge you to keep your doors shut, Is'bel ? and do you let 'em lie open for all comers?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.l: Friend know some cause, before thou beatest thy wife,
This is madness, in thee.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Why? is there no cause?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.l: Yes, I'll show cause before the justice, Cob:
come, let her go with me.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Nay, she shall go.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Nay, I will go. I'll see, an' you may be allowed to make a bundle of hemp, of your right and lawful wife thus, at every cuckoldly knave's pleasure. Why do you not go?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: A bitter quean. Come, we'll ha' you tamed.

Well, of all my disguises, yet, now am I most like myself: being in this sergeants gown. A man of my present profession, never counterfeits, till he lays hold upon a debtor, and says, he rests him, for then he brings him to all manner of unrest. A kind of little Kings we are, bearing the diminutive of a mace, made like a young artichoke, that always carries pepper and salt, in itself. Well, I know not what danger I undergo, by this exploit, pray heaven, I come well of.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: See, I think, yonder is the varlet, by his gown.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Let's go, in quest of him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: 'save you, friend, are not you here, by appointment of justice Clement's man.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Yes, an't please you, sir: he told me two gentlemen had willled him to procure a warrant from his master (Which I have about me) to be served on one downright.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: It is honestly done of you both; and see, where the party comes, you must arrest: serve it upon him, quickly, afore he be aware —

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Bear back, master Matthew.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Master downright, I arrest you, i'the Queen's name, and must carry you afore a justice, by virtue of this warrant.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Me, friend? I am no downright, I. I am master Stephen, you do not well, to arrest me, I tell you, truly: I am in nobody's bonds, nor books, I, would you should know it. A plague on you heartily, for making me thus afraid afore my time.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Why, now are you deceived, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: He wears such a cloak, and that deceived us: but see, here 'a comes, indeed! this is he, officer.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Why how now, signior gull! are you turned filcher of late? come, deliver my cloak.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Your cloak, sir? I bought it, even now, in open market.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Master Downright, I have a warrant I must serve upon you, procured by these two gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: These gentlemen? these rascals?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Keep the peace, I charge you, in her majesty's name.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: I obey thee. What must I do, officer?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Go before, master justice Clement, to answer what they can object against you, sir. I will use you kindly, sir.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: Come, let's before, and make the justice, captain —

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: The varlet's a tall man! afore heaven!

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Gull, you'll give me my cloak?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Sir, I bought it, and I'll keep it.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: You will.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Ay, that I will.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Officer, there's thy fee, arrest him.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Master Stephen, I must arrest you.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Arrest me, I scorn it. There, take your cloak, I'll none of't.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Nay, that shall not serve your turn, now, sir. Officer, I'll go with thee, to the justices: bring him along.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Why, is not here your cloak? what would you have?

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: I'll ha'you answer it, sir.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Sir, I'll take your word; and this gentleman's, too: for his appearance.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: I'll ha' no words taken. Bring him along.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Sir, I may choose, to do that: I may take bail.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: 'Tis true, you may take bail, and choose; at another time: but you shall not, now, varlet. Bring him along, or I'll swinge you.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Sir, I pity the gentleman's case. Here's your money again.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: 'sdeynes, tell not me of my money, bring him away, I say.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I warrant you he will go with you of himself, sir.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Yet more ado?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I have made a fair mash on't.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Must I go?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I know no remedy, master Stephen.

sp.speaker: Down.
sp.p: Come along, afore me, here. I do not love your hanging look behind.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Why, sir. I hope you cannot hang me for it. Can he, fellow?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: I think not, sir. It is but a whipping matter, sure!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: Why, then, let him do his worst, I am resolute.

div.head: Act v. scene i.
div.stage: Clement, Kno'wel, Kitely, dame Kitely, Tib, Cash, Cob, servants.

sp.p: Nay, but stay, stay, give me leave: my chair, sirrah. You, master Kno'well, say you went thither to meet your son.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Ay, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: But, who directed you, thither?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: That did mine own man, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Nay, I know not, now; I left him with your clerk: and appointed him, to stay here for me.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: My dark? about what time, was this?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Marry, between one and two, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: And, what time came my man with the false message to you, master Kitely?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: After two, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Very good: but, mistress Kitely, how that you were at Cons? ha?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: An' please you, sir, I'll tell you: my brother, Wellbred, told me, that Cob's house, was a suspected place —

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: So it appears, methinks : but, on.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And that my husband used thither, daily.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: No matter, so he used himself well, mistress.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: True sir, but you know, what grows, by such haunts, oftentimes.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I see, rank fruits of a jealous brain, mistress Kitely: but, did you find your husband there, in that case, as you suspected?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: I found her there, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Did you so? that alters the case. Who gave you knowledge, of your wives being there?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: Marry, that did my brother Wellbred.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: How? Wellbred first tell her? then tell you, after? where is Wellbred?

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: Gone with my sister, sir, I know not whither.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Why, this is a mere trick, a device; you are gulled in this most grossly, all! alas, poor wench, wert thou beaten for this?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Yes, most pitifully, and 't please you.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: And worthily, I hope: if it shall prove so.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Ay, that's like, and a piece of a sentence. How now, sir? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, there's a gentleman, i' the court without, desires to speak with your worship.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: A gentleman? what's he?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: A soldier, sir, he says.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: A soldier? take down my armour, my sword, quickly: a soldier speak with me!he arms himself. why, when knaves? come on, come on, hold my cap there, so; give me my gorget, my sword: stand by, I will end your matters, enough — let the soldier enter, now, sir, what ha'you to say to me?
By your worship's favour —

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Nay, keep out, sir, I know not your pretence, you send me word, sir, you are a soldier: why, sir, you shall be answered, here, here be them have been amongst soldiers. Sir, your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Faith, sir, so it is, this gentleman, and myself, have been most uncivilly wronged, and beaten, by one downright, a course fellow, about the town, here, and for mine own part, I protest, being a man, in no sort, given to this filthy humour of quarrelling, he hath assaulted me in the way of my peace; despoiled me of mine honour; disarmed me of my weapons; and rudely, laid me along, in the open streets: when, I not so much as once offered to resist him.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: O, gods precious! is this the soldier? here, take my armour of quickly, 'twill make him swoon, I fear; he is not fit to look on't, that will put up a blow.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.p: An't please your worship, he was bound to the peace.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Why, and he were, sir, his hands were not bound, were they?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: There's one of the varlets of the city, sir, has brought two gentlemen, here, one, upon your worships warrant.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: My warrant?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes, sir. The officer says, procured by these two.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Bid him, come in. Set by this picture. What, Mr. Downright! are you brought at Mr. fresh-waters suit, here!
i'faith, sir. And here's another brought at my suit.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: What are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: A gentleman, sir? O, uncle!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Uncle? who? master Kno'well?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Ay, sir! this is a wise kinsman of mine.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: God's my witness, uncle, I am wronged here monstrously, he charges me with stealing of his cloak, and would I might never stir, if I did not find it in the street, by chance.

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: O, did you find it, now? you said, you bought it, erewhile.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: And, you said, I stole it; nay, now my uncle is here, I'll do well enough, with you.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Well, let this breath a while; you, that have cause to complain, there, stand forth: had you my warrant for this gentleman's apprehension?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Ay, an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Nay, do not speak in passion so: where had you it?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: Of your clerk, sir?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: That's well! an' my clerk can make warrants, and my hand not at 'em! Where is the warrant? Officer, have you it?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: No, sir, your worship's man, master formal, bid me do it, for these gentlemen, and he would be my discharge.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Why, master downright, are you such a novice, to be served, and never see the warrant?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Sir. He did not serve it on me.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: No? how then?

sp.speaker: Dow.
sp.p: Marry, sir, he came to me, and said, he must serve it, and he would use me kindly, and so —

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: O, gods pity, was it so, sir? he must serve it? give me my longsword there, and help me of; so. Come on, sir varlet, I must cut off your legs,he flourishes overhim with his longsword. sirrah: nay, stand up, I'll use you kindly; I must cut off your legs, I say.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: O, good sir, I beseech you; nay, good master justice.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I must do it; there is no remedy. I must cut off your legs, sirrah, I must cut off your ears, you rascal, I must do it; I must cut off your nose, I must cut off your head.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: O, good your worship.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Well, rise, how dost thou do, now? dost thou feel thyself well? hast thou no harm?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: No, I thank your good worship, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Why, so! I said, I must cut off thy legs, and I must cut off thy arms, and I must cut off thy head; but, I did not do it: so, you said, you must serve this gentleman, with my warrant, but, you did not serve him. You knave, you slave, you rogue, do you say you must? sirrah, away with him, to the jail, I'll teach you a trick, for your must, sir.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Good, sir, I beseech you, be good to me.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Tell him he shall to the jail, away with him, I say ▪

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Nay, sir, if you will commit me, it shall be for committing more than this: I will not lose, by my travail, any grain of my fame certain.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: How is this!

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: My man, Brainworm!

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: O yes, uncle. Brainworm has been with my cousin Edward, and I, all this day.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I told you all, there was some device!

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Nay, excellent justice, since I have laid myself thus open to you; now, stand strong for me: both with your sword, and your balance.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Body o'me, a merry knave! Give me a bowl of sack: if he belong to you, master Kno'well, I bespeak your patience.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: That is it, I have most need of. Sir, if you'll pardon me, only; I'll glory in all the rest, of my exploits.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Sir, you know, I love not to have my favours come hard, from me. You have your pardon: though I suspect you shrewdly for being of counsel with my son, against me.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Yes, faith, I have, sir; though you retained me doubly this morning, for yourself: first, as Brainworm; after, as Fitz-sword. I was your reformed soldier, sir. 'twas I sent you to cobs, upon the errand, without end.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: Is it possible! or that thou shouldst disguise thy language so, as I should not know thee?

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: O, sir, this has been the day of my metamorphosis! It is not that shape alone that I have run through, today. I brought this gentleman, master Kitely, a message too, in the form of master justice's man, here, to draw him out of the way, as well as your worship: while master Well-bred might make a conveyance of mistress Bridget, to my young master.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p: How! my sister stolen away?

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: My son is not married, I hope!

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Faith, sir, they are both as sure as love, a priest, and three thousand pound (Which is her portion) can make 'em: and by this time are ready to bespeak their wedding supper at the windmill, except some friend, here, prevent 'em, and invite 'em home.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Marry, that will I (I thank thee, for putting me in mind on't.) Sirrah, go you, and fetch 'em hither, upon my warrant. Neither's friends have cause to be sorry, if I know the young couple, aright. Here, I drink to thee, for thy good news. But, I pray thee, what hast thou done with my man formal.

sp.speaker: Bray.
sp.p: Faith, sir, after some ceremony past, as making him drunk, first with story, and then with wine (But all in kindness) and stripping him to his shirt: I left him in that cool vain, departed, sold your worships warrant to these two, pawned his livery for that varlet's gown, to serve it in; and thus have brought myself, by my activity, to your worship's consideration.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
And I will consider thee, in another cup of sack. Here's to thee, which having drunk of, this is my sentence. Pledge me. Thou hast done,
or assisted to nothing, in my judgement, but deserves to be pardoned for the wit of the offence. If thy master, or any man, here, be angry with thee, I shall suspect his engine, while I know him for't. How now? what noise is that!

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, it is Roger is come home.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Bring him in, bring him in. What! drunk in arms, against me? Your reason, your reason for this.
I beseech your worship to pardon me; I happened into ill company by chance, that cast me into a sleep, and stripped me of all my clothes —

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Well, tell him, I am justice Clement, and do pardon him: but, what is this to your armour! what may that signify?

sp.speaker: Form.
sp.p: And 't please you, sir, it hung up i' the room, where I was stripped; and I borrowed it of one of the drawers, to come home in, because I was loath, to do penance through the street, i' my shirt.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Well, stand by a while. Who be these? O, the young company, welcome, welcome. Give you joy. Nay, mistress Bridget, blush not; you are not so fresh a bride, but the news of it is come hither afore you. Master bridegroom, I ha' made your peace, give me your hand: so will I for all the rest, ere you forsake my roof.
We are the more bound to your humanity, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Only these two, have so little of man in 'em, they are no part of my care.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Yes, sir, let me pray you for this gentleman, he belongs, to my sister, the bride.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: In what place, sir?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Of her delight, sir, below the stairs, and in public: her poet, sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
A poet? I will challenge him myself, presently, at extempore.
Mount up thy Phlegon muse, and testify,
How Saturn, sitting in an ebon cloud,
Disrobed his podex white as ivory,
And, through the welkin, thundered all aloud.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: He is not for extempore, sir. He is all for the pocket-muse, please you command a sight of it.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Yes, yes, search him for a taste of his vein.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: You must not deny the Queen's justice, sir, under a writ of rebellion.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
What! all this verse? Body of me, he carries a whole realm, a commonwealth of paper, in's hose! let's see some of his subjects!
Unto the boundless ocean of thy face,
Runs this poor river changed with streams of eyes. how? this is stolen!

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: A Parody! A parody! with a kind of miraculous gift, to make it absurd then it was.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Is all the rest, of this batch? Being me a torch; lay it together, and give fire. Cleanse the air. He was enough to have infected, the whole city, if it had not been taken in time! See, see, how our poet's glory shines! brighter, and brighter! Still it increases! O, now, it's at the highest: and, now, it declines as fast. You may see. Sic transit gloria mundi.

sp.speaker: Kno.
sp.p: There's an emblem for you, son, and your studies!

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Nay, no speech, or act of mine be drawn against such as profess it worthily. They are not born every year, as an alderman. There goes more to the making of a good poet, than a sheriff, mr. Kitely. You look upon me! though, I live i' the city here, amongst you, I will do more reverence, to him, when I meet him, than I will to the major, out of his year. But, these paper-pedlars! these ink-dabblers! They cannot expect reprehension, or reproach. They have it with the fact.

sp.speaker: E. Kn.
sp.p: Sir, you have saved me the labour of a defence.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: It shall be discourse for supper; between your father and me, if he dare undertake me. But, to dispatch away these, you sign of the soldier, and picture of the poet (But, both so false, I will not ha' you hanged out at my door till midnight) while we are at supper, you two shall penitently fast it out in my court, without; and, if you will, you may pray there, that we may be so merry within, as to forgive, or forget you ▪ when we come out. Here's a third, because, we tender your safety, shall watch you, he is provided for the purpose. Look to your change, sir.

sp.speaker: S●e●.
sp.p: And what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: O! I had lost a sheep, an he had not bleated! Why, sir, you shall give Mr. Downright his cloak: and I will entreat him to take it. A trencher, and a napkin, you shall have, i' the buttery, and keep Cob, and his wife company, here; whom, I will entreat first to be reconciled: and you to endeavour with your wit, to keep 'em so.

sp.speaker: S●●●.
sp.p: I'll do my best.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.p: Why, now I see thou art honest, Tib, I receive thee as my dear, and mortal wife, again.

sp.speaker: Ti●.
sp.p: And, I you, as my loving, and obedient husband.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Good compliment! It will be their bridal night too. They
are married anew. Come, I conjure the rest, to put of all discontent. You, mr. Downright, your anger; you, master Kno'well, your cares; master Kitely, and his wife, their jealousy.
sp.l: For, I must tell you both, while that is fed,
Horns i' the mind are worse than of the head.

sp.speaker: Kite.
sp.p:
Sir, thus they go from me, kiss me, sweet heart.
See, what a drove of horns fly, in the air,
Winged with my densed, and my credulous breath!
Watch 'em, suspicious eyes, watch, where they fall.
See, see! on hands, that think they've none at all!
O, what a plenteous world of this, will come!
When air rains horns, all may be sure of same. I ha' learned so much verse out of a jealous man's part, in a play.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: 'Tis well, 'tis well! This night we'll dedicate to friendship, love, and laughter. Master bridegroom, take your bride, and lead: every one, a fellow. Here is my mistress. Brainworm! to whom all my addresses of courtship shall have their reference. Whose adventures, this day, when our grandchildren shall hear to be made a fable, I doubt not, but it shall find both spectators, and applause.

div.p: This comedy was first acted, in the year 1598.
By the then l. Chamberlayne his servants.
With the allowance of the master of revels.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
